I had rather looke like an Asse, as I am still.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: Bee not too boistrous, my sonne of thunder.
Wee are wel-wishers to thy campe, and thee,
Here is a freshman, I would haue acquainted
With the mystery of your iniquity.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: I do imbrace thy league, and returne the hand
Of friendship. To thy better vnderstanding,
I will discouer the situation of the place.
Tis of it selfe an Iland, a meere Swans nest:
Which had Vlisses seene, he would prefer
Before his Ithaca, and he whom Fate
Shall blesse to vanquish it; Hee may deserue
The name of a new conquerour. It has
The credit, to bee styl'd the Terra florida,
Of the best beautyes in the Towne, my friend,
That repaire hither vpon the least summons,
Besides some that are constant to their trenches.
Venus in his house is predominant.
Tis barren, I confesse. Yet wholy giuen
To the deeds of fructication. But those
Are barrd from comming to perfection,
With Rhewmes, and diseases. You Dormise,
What must I reade a lecture to you gratis?

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: No sir, here's money for you.

sp.speaker: Pander,
sp.l: You may enter,
And returne safe, vpon your good behauiour.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.l: Well, they may talke of Dunkerke, or of Callis,
Enricht with forraine booties, but if euer
A little Garrison, or sconce, as this,
Were so fild vp with spoyles, let me be carted.

sp.speaker: 1. Whore.
sp.l: And carry it so cunningly away,
Beyond the reach of Iustice, and of all
The iurisdiction in our owne hand,
Like a free state.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.l: Did not I purchase it?
And am not I the Lady of the Mannor?
And who shall dare to question mee? I hope,
I shall be able to defend my Fort,
From the inuasion of the painted staffe,
Or the tempestuous paper Engine, safe,
As a Moale in a Trench, and worke at hie midnight.
When their wise heads are layd, wee'l rayse the spirits
Of our dead pleasures, vse the benefit
Of youth, and dance our Orgyes by the Moonelight.

sp.speaker: 1. Whore.
sp.l: I hope they need not to condemne vs, wee driue
As open trade as they, and vent as ill
Commodities, as any: all that we vtter,
Is in darke shoppes, or else by candlelight.

sp.speaker: 2. Whore.
sp.p: We are become the enuy of Citizens.

sp.speaker: 1. Whore.
sp.p: It is reported that we study physicke.

sp.speaker: 1. Whore.
sp.l: The reason is, because we know
The seuerall constitutions of mens bodies.

sp.speaker: 2. Whore.
sp.p: And some tearme vs the Leager.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.l: We defye
The force of any man, who's that knocks so?
Go bid the watch looke out, and if their number
Be not too plurall, then let them come in.
But if they chance to bee those ruffian Souldiers,
Let fall the purcullis. All they can do,
Is to discharge a volley of oathes at me.
Ile take no tickets, nor no future stipends.
Tis not false titles, or denominations
Of offices can do it. I must haue money.
Tell them so, draw the bridge. Ile make them know,
This is no widdowes house, but Marcus Manitius,
Is Lord of the Iland, Who wast?

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.l: Pox on the Marshall, and the Constable.
There cannot be a Mystery in a Trade,
But they must peepe into it. Mercilesse varlets,
That know how many fall by our occupation,
And yet would haue their Venery for nothing.
A chambermayd can't haue a Ruffe to set,
But they must bee poking in it;
Now they haue brought vs vnder contribution,
They vex vs more then the Venetians doe
The whole Corporation of Curtezans:
But we must giue good words, shew them a roome.

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.l: There's hot seruice within, I heare the Muskets
Play from the Rampiers. I am valiant,
And will venter vpon the very mouthes of them.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.l: Mr. Ardelio, you haue beene a stranger.
You are growne rich of late.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.p: Yes somewhat pursy for want of exercise.

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.l: Well, I was wont to put in for a gamester.
But now I am quite thrust out of all play.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.l: We were wont to be your subiects to worke on,
And since you scorne vs, yet you cannot say,
But you haue found good dealing at our hands.

sp.speaker: 2. Whore.
sp.l: We haue bin alwaies bent to your worships will
And forward to helpe you on at all times.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.l: Truely sir you know,
I keepe as good creatures at liuery,
And as cheape too, as any poore sinner
Of my profession.

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.l: Hast thou ere a morsell,
That is not tainted, or flye blowne?

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.l: Indeede I haue
So much adoe to keepe my family sound,
You would wonder at it: and such as are so,
They are taken vp presently. But I haue one,
I dare commend to you, for wind and limme.

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.p: Come, let me haue her then.

sp.speaker: Miscel.
sp.l: Its strange there is no more attendance giuen,
To vsher in a man of my quality.
Are you the Gouernesse of this Cinqueport, Lady?

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.l: The fortresse, sir, is mine, and none come here,
But pay me custome.

sp.speaker: Miscel.
sp.l: Hast thou nere a Pilot,
Or man of warre to conduct a man safe
Into thy Harbour? there be roagues abroade.
Piraticall varlets that would pillage mee.

sp.speaker: Miscel.
sp.p: I thought at first, you would haue bard my entrance.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.l: I doe not vse the fashions of those Countries,
That keepe a stranger out foure weekes at sea,
To know if hee bee sound. I make no scruple,
But giue free traffique to all Nations.
If you haue payd your due, you may put in,
There is the way, Ile follow presently.
I thinke our souldiers are all come, lets in
And set the watch.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: Stay punke, make roome for vs,
That haue aduanc'd our banners to thy walls,
Past all the pikes, the perdues, and the Centries.
Tis a good Omen, whers Bellona there,
And the daughters of Mars, those braue Girles?
We are come to pay our homage to their smockes.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.p: Nay, if you are vnruly, we shall tame you.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: Feare not, wee are tributaries, punke.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.l: Sir, doe you speake with no more reuerence
To me? it seemes you know me not

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: I shall
Endeauour to preserue thy dignity,
Art thou that braue Hyppolite, that gouernes
This troupe of Scythians? Speake, Orsthya,
My Menalippe, my Antiope
Wee are sworne vassals to your petticoates.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.l: Did you attempt but the least iniury,
There be in readines, would vindicate
The wrongs, and credit of my house.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: I know
Thy power, punke, and do submit me, punke,
Tam Marti, quam Veneri. Tis thy Motto, punke.

sp.speaker: Caprit.
sp.p: Would I could tell how to get out againe.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.p: How came you in? haue you performd all duties?

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: I threw thy Cerberus a sleepy Morsell,
And payd thy Charon for my waftage ouer.
And I haue a golden sprig for my Proserpine.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: Nay I do honour
Thee, and thy house, and all thy vermine in't.
And thou dost well to stand vpon thy guard,
Spight of the statutes. Tis a Castle this,
A Fort, a Metrapolitan bawdy house.
A Cynosarges, such as Hercules
Built in the honour of his pedegree,
For entertainment of the bastard issue
Of the bold Spartan.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.l: You haue sayd enough, sir.
And for requitall, I will shew you in,
Where you shall read the titles, and the prices.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: But here's a brother of mine is somewhat bashfull:
I'd faine deliuer him to thy discipline.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.l: What, is he bashfull? that's a fault indeed.
Come hither, chops, you must not be so shamefac'd?

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: Loe you there, sir, you shall come forth in print.
March on, my Calypso, come sir, follow your colours.
You shall haue the leading of the first title,

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.l: Put it on your face.
Now they are housd, Ile watch their comming forth,
And fright them in the forme of a Constable,
If that succeeds well, then Ile change the person,
To a Iustice of peace, and you shall act
My clarke Autolicus. They say an officer
Dares not appeare about the Gates: Ile try it.
For I haue made one drunke, and got his staffe.
Which I will vse with more authority,
Then Mercury his all-commanding rod,
To charme their steps, that none shall passe this way;
Without examination. There stalkes one,
Ile first know what he is; now they drop away,
As if they leapt out from the Troian horse;
This is the Autumne of the night: who goes there?

sp.speaker: Antol.
sp.p: Friend, or foe, come before the Constable,

sp.speaker: Ardel.
sp.l: And't please you Sir, I haue
Been wayting on my neece, home to her lodging.

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.l: Why, is your Neece a Leagerer, a suttler,
Or Laundresse to this Fort?

sp.speaker: Ardel.
sp.l: No, and it like you,
Shee lyes without the campe.

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.l: You lye like a Pimpe.
You are an Apple-squire, a Rat, and a Ferret.
I saw you bolt out from that Conney-berry.

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.l: Out of the wind of mee what do you thinke,
You can put out the eyes of a gorcrow?
Fob mee off so, the Constable, that haue
The parish stock of witt in my hands? I am glad,
That I haue got you from your couert. You shall
Bee learcht, you shall along with me sir.

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.l: No farther then to prison, where you shall pay,
But forty shillings for noctiuagation.

sp.speaker: Ardel.
sp.l: I am vndone then. There are forty old scores,
I owe in Towne, will follow after mee.

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.p: What are you? whats your name?

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.l: Ardelio,
A Lords seruant.

sp.speaker: Ardel.
sp.l: Alas, a veniall sinne, wee vse to learne it,
When wee come first to be pages.

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.p: Stand by, ther's one has got a clap too.

sp.speaker: Miscel.
sp.p: The shirt of Hersuses was not so hot.

sp.speaker: Snarle.
sp.p: Ther's one sure has beene hurt with a Gronieado.

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.l: No body. My senses fayle mee then, who ist?
What man are you?

sp.speaker: Miscel.
sp.l: No man, you are deceiu'd,
I can not find I am a man, that part
Is dead, wherein I once was an Achilles:

sp.speaker: Miscel.
sp.p: I can not go, I haue lost my nerues.

sp.speaker: Antol.
sp.p: You shall be carryed to the Iayle then.

sp.speaker: Miscel.
sp.l: Fitter
For an Hospitall. I am condemned already
To fluxes, and dyer drinkes.

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.p: Who's that Heronimoes sonnes ghost in the Garden?

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: O Mr. Constable, wee haue beene so vsde,
As neuer two aduentrous Gentlemen
In the hands of their enemies.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: Let mee take breath: I am at the last gaspe.
We haue eskapt from the denne of the Cyclops,
There was one ranne a spit against my eyes.

sp.speaker: Caprit.
sp.l: Amongst the rest, there was a blinke-eyed woman
Set a great dog vpon mee.

sp.speaker: Trm.
sp.l: They haue spoyld vs
Of our cloakes, our hats, our swords, and our money.

sp.speaker: Snarle.
sp.p: Your wits, and credit were both lost before.

sp.speaker: Caprit.
sp.p: No, wee had not our wits about vs then.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: Good sir, let's thinke on some reuenge, call vp
The Gentlemen prentises, and make a Shrouetuesday.

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.p: By no meanes, I must suppresse all violence.

sp.speaker: Caprit.
sp.l: My brother talkt of building of a sconce,
And straight they seazd our cloakes for the reckoning.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: There I lost my hat and sword in the reskew.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: And whilst some stroue to hold my hands,
The other diu'd in my pockets. I am sure,
There was a fellow with a tand face, whose breath
Was growne sulphurous with oathes and tobacco,
Puft terror in my face, I shal neuer bee
Mine owne man againe.

sp.speaker: 1 Who.
sp.p: Twere a good deed to haue made them swim the mote.

sp.speaker: 2 Who.
sp.p: I, to haue stript them, and sent them out naked.

sp.speaker: 1 Who.
sp.l: Let's sally out, and fetch them in againe.
Then call a court on them for false alarums.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: Flye from their rage, sir; they are worse then Harpyes,
They'll teare vs, as the Thracians did Orpheus,
Whose Musicke, though it charmd the powers of Hell,
Could not bee heard amongst these. Mr. Ardelio
And Miscellanio, I ioy to see you,
Though ill met here.

sp.speaker: Miscel.
sp.l: Signiour Trimalchio,
Sir you must pardon me. I can not stoope.
I haue the Grincums in my backe, I feare
Will spoyle my courtship.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: Mr. Ardelio,
Who would expected to haue met you here?

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.l: Nay, who would not expect it? tis my haunt.
I loue it, as a pigeon, loues a salt-pit.

sp.speaker: Miscel.
sp.l: O mee! my scholler too how came he hither?
I did not meane t'impart this mystery.
How could hee find it out?

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: His owne Minerua,
And my helpt, sir.

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.l: Marry, before a Iustice,
To answere for your ryot.

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.p: I can not dispence with it.

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.p: Not before next sessions. Bring them away.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.l: Was euer such a treacherous plot intended,
Against our State, and dignity?

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: Had this
Past with impunity, they might haue sworne,
Vengeance had runne the country.

sp.speaker: 1. Whore.
sp.l: But I hope,
They haue no cause to boast their victory,

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: Now by this aire, as I am a true souldier,
Bred vnder, and deuoted to your Banne,
But that your pitty did preuent my rage,
They should haue knowne no quarter, for this brow
Brookes no affronts.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.l: Wee'l haue a stone grauen with characters.
To intimate your prowesse.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: No, my deare Gorgons,
I will not haue my same wander without
The precincts of your Castell: tis enough
It can be sheltred heere, within these walls.
And to recount with your acknowledgements,
What this Fort owes to my protection.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.p: Captaine, wee must confesse you are our Guardian.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: Then let mee sacrifice vnto my humour.
All you this night, shall be at my disposing,
To drinke and drab, tis the fault of your fortune
That do professe this trade, t'haue somebody,
To spend your purchase on, tis my decree,
What others ryot, you should waste on me.

div.head: Actus 4. Scene 4.
div.stage: Agurtes like a Iustice of peace. Antelicus his Clarke.

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.l: Then let mee see
How I can act it: do I looke like a Iustice?

sp.speaker: Antol.
sp.p: As fearefull as an Asse in a Lyons skinne, sir.

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.l: Here I begin my state. Suppose mee now
Come downe the staires, out of the dining roome,
Into the hall, and thus I begin. Brisco.
Call Brisco my Clarke.

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.l: Reach mee my ensigne of authority,
My staffe I meane. Fy, fy, how dull you are,
And incomposed? Now set me in my chaire,
That I may looke like a Cathedrall Iustice,
That knew, what belongs to an Assignanimus,
And Dedimus potestatis. Nay, though we are
Of the peace, wee can giue Priscian a knocke.
Let mee alone now to determine causes,
As free from error as the Pope. Old Minos,
And Rhadmanth, are not so skilld ith vrne,
As I am in the statutes. I haue them ad vnguem
Now if they enter, at their perill bee it.
How dost thou like my action?

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.l: Let them come in.
sp.stage: Enter Snarle like a Constable. Trimalchio, Capritio, Miscellanio, Ardelio.
sp.l: Now Mr Constable,
I must commend your diligence. Come hither.

sp.speaker: Snarl.
sp.l: Sir I haue brough foure men before your Worship,
I found last night, at midnight, in the streets,
Raysing a tumult.

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.l: Brisco, bee ready to take
Their examination. Good: you found foure men,
At midnight. Whose men are they?

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.l: So it seemes by your Liueries.
Write that downe; first they say, they are their owne men.

sp.speaker: Ardel.
sp.p: Sir, by your fauour, I am not my owne man.

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.l: I thought they would not all bee in one tale,
I knew I should find them tripping, and I
Once come to sift them. You are not your owne man.
It argues you are drunke. Write his confession,
Ex os tuum te iudico: perge Mr. Constable.

sp.speaker: Snarle.
sp.l: I hold it fit, your Worship should examine
What they did there so late,

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.l: What did you there
So late?

sp.speaker: Miscel.
sp.p: Good Iustice Eccho, wee had busines.

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.l: Record, they say they had busines. They shall know.
That I am Iudge of Record, and what I do
Record, shal stand, and they shal haue no power
To plead not guilty in a Scire facias,
By a Recognisance. I haue my termes.

sp.speaker: Ardel
sp.p: Good your Worship, giue vs not such hard words.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: Tis almost as hard vsage as the Leager.

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.p: Then you came from the Leager?

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: You may reade
Some aduentures in our habit, wee haue seene,
And tasted the experience of the warres.

sp.speaker: Miscel.
sp.l: They haue made me of another religion,
I must turne Iew, I thinke, and bee circumcised.
I may be any thing, now I shall lose a Limme.
I may goe seeke my pension with the souldiers.
But tis no matter, I'll turne valiant,
And fight with the stumpe.

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.l: You are a fighter then.
This doth appeare to mee, to bee a ryot.
What thinke you, Mr. Constable?

sp.speaker: Snarle.
sp.l: I know not
What you meane, but I meane as your Worship meanes.
I did perceiue they had beene quarelling.

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.l: Why then 'twas an affray, a sudden affray,
Directly against the State of Northampton.
The Decimo tertio of Harry the fourth cleares the doubt.
How doe you trauerse this? what doe you answere?

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.l: We make a question, by your Worships fauour,
Vnder correction, whether that which was
Done vnder forraine powers, in forraine Lands,
Be punishable heere or no.

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.l: Tis a prouince by it selfe, a priuiledg'd place,
A strong corporation, and has factions
In Court and Citty.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: Is inhabited
With furies, that do multiply like Hydra:
An army of diseases can't suppresse them,
Besides their many fallings t'other way.

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.l: I should be loth t'infringe their liberties,
Ile send you to betryed, from whence you came then.

sp.speaker: Caprit.
sp.l: O good your Worship, hang vs vp at home first,
Let vs indure the racke or the strappado,
We do submit vs to your Worships censure.

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.p: Haue you prouided sureties for the peace then?

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.l: More neede to prouide somethings for my belly.
I thinke they meane to keepe me for a race.
I am falne away quite, I was like a hogshead.
Now I amable to runne thorow my hoopes.

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.l: Whats he that halts before me? doe you mocke me?
Tis ill halting before a cripple, sirah

sp.speaker: Miscel.
sp.l: This sore against my will, I can not helpe it.
Would I could runne away with halfe my teeth.

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.l: Can't a man haue the venerable gowt,
Or the bone-ache, but you must imitate him?

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.l: Mocke your fellow rogues.
I am none of those, that raysd my fortunes with
Fiddling and Tobacco. Make his Mittimus.

sp.speaker: Snarle.
sp.p: And't please you sir, here's one has brought a Letter.

sp.speaker: Snarle.
sp.l: He sayes, from one Mistrisse Millescent,
The contents will informe you.

stage.p:
NOble sir, I am sorry to interest my unstaynd honour in the patronage of offendors, or to abuse the credit I haue with you, in stopping the course of Iustice against them, whose youthfull licenciousnesse, would pollute the pen of a Lady to excuse it. On the other part, J hold it the betraying of a virgins sweete disposition, to withdraw her fauours, where she has once plac'd them, although there be some want of desert. I must confesse tis an Antipathy to my nature, to see any Gentleman suffer, when I may preuent it. Howsoeuer I haue found a disrespect from him, yet I forget it. For anger abides in the bosomes of women, as snow on the ground: where it is smooth and leuell, it fals quickly off, but remaynes where it is rough and vneuen. That this may appeare to bee true, I would intreate you to dismisse those two Gentlemen and their associates, Mr. Trimalchio, and Capritio, whose ryotous loosenesse has made them obnoxious to your censure, and my suspicion. Thus
not doubting the successe of my letter, I rest in your fauour as you may presume on mine, and your true friend,

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.l: This Lady, that has writ in your behalfe,
Is one I honour.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: How could she heare of it?

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.l: It seemes, your fault is quickly blowne abroad.
〈…〉 rather seale a Nouerint vniuersi,
For a thousand pound stale commodities,
Then thee should know of it.

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.l: As for you two,
You may pay your fees and depart, you haue
Your manumission, or this Ladies sake.
Master. Constable, you are discharg'd, and you may
Goe along with them and receiue their fees.

sp.speaker: Mis.
sp.l: Though I say nothing, yet I smell something:
A Lady send a letter? Shee is, in loue
With me, Ile pawne my life, and I nere knew it.
I'le get my backe well, and goe visit her.

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.l: Now I haue got my teeth at liberty,
And they ere tye me to the racke againe,
Let me be choakt.

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.l: Well, I perceiue you are
A fauourite to this Lady. Whats your name?

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.p: Two ancient names in Camden, Of what country?

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.l: The Capritios of Norfolke.
I thinke we shall bee kin anon. My mother
Was a Capritie, and of that house;
Are you alyed vnto this Lady?

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: No sir.
But I haue formerly beene entertain'd
As a poore tutor to her graces fauour.

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.l: I finde by that, you are a man of fashion.
And would you then?

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: Nay good sir, doe not chide.

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.l: Yes, I must tell you, that you were to blame,
Hauing so faire a fortune before you, to wrong
A Lady of her spirit; so rich, and faire,
Of vnreprooued chastity, and one
So high in birth, nay 'tis not possible
To speake her vertues, and present your selfe
So lumpishly, nay perhaps fill her bed
Full of diseases.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: Good sir, say no more.
I am a traytor, I haue kild a man,
Committed sacriledge. Let her seeke reuenge
For these, or if lesse punishment will serue:
To haue me beaten, Ile runne naked to her.

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.l: I will not presse a good nature so farre:
You two shall stay and dine with me. Ile send
My coach for your Mistris, it shall goe hard:
But I will make you friends, before we part.

sp.speaker: Faust.
sp.l: Now let mee bid you welcome from the warres,
Laden with conquest, and the golden fleece
Of honour, which like Iason, you haue brought
T'inrich your Country, now indebted to you.
Had it not beene a pitty such a talent
Of vertue should be lost or ill imployd?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Lady, you are a good Physicion,
It was your counsel wrought this miracle,
Beyond the power of Aesculapius:
For when my mind was stupified, and lost
In the pursuit of pleasures: all my body
Torne, and dissected with close vanityes,
You haue collected me anew to life:
And now I come to you, with as chaste thoughts,
As they were first adulterous, and yeeld
A due submission for the wrong I did
Both to your selfe, and sex.

sp.speaker: Faust.
sp.l: Sir. for my part,
You haue your pardon.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: You were borne to quit mee.

sp.speaker: Fude.
sp.l: But when you know the Authour of your freedome,
You'll thanke her more.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Who? not Faustina? shee told me so indeed,
Her name was Faustina. Let mee looke vpon her,
As on the picture of all goodnesse, engrauen
By a celestiall finger, shall weare out:
A marble character. I knew her not,
I am glad there is a scion of our stock.
Can beare such fruit as this, so ripe in vertue.
Where haue you liu'd recluse? you were betrothd
To one Fidelio; but crost by your father.
I haue heard good reports of the Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Faust.
sp.l: I neuer knew you flatter any man
Vnto his face before.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Vnto his face?
Where is hee?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I am transported, rauisht: giue mee leaue
Good gods, to entertaine with reuerence,
So great a comfort. Let mee first embrace you.
Great ioyes, like greifes, are silent. Loose mee now,
And let me make you fast. Here ioyne your hands,
Which no age shall vnty. Let happinesse
Distill from you, as the Arabian gummes,
To blesse your issue.

sp.speaker: Fidel.
sp.l: Now I hope, sweet Lady,
The time has put a period to your vow.

sp.speaker: Faust.
sp.l: Tis ended now, and you may take a comfort,
That I could tye my selfe to such a law.
For you may hope thereby, I shall obserue you
With no lesse strict obedience.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: And for her dowry, I will treble it,
Heere Sanrle is come to be a witnesse to it.

sp.speaker: Snarle.
sp.l: My Lord Philautus, if I may presume
To congratulate your Honours safe returne,
I must confesse, I doe it with my heart,
And all your friends long to participate
Your happy presence.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Thankes both to them and thee.

sp.speaker: Snarle.
sp.l: Master Fidelio, no lesse to you.
I see you happy in your Mistris fauour:
And thats as much, as I can wish to you.

sp.speaker: Fidel.
sp.l: You haue bin alwaies priuy to my counsell
Aske me no questions now, I shall resolue you
When we come in.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: How fares our Campe at home,
Trimalchio, and the rest?

sp.speaker: Snarle.
sp.l: I haue beene busie,
In proiecting for them, they must all bee married.
I haue seene the interlude of the Leager:
And we haue playd the Iustice, and the Constable:
I will not prepossesse you with the sport,
But I will shew you such a scene of laughter.

sp.speaker: Snarle.
sp.l: Your seruant Ardelio.
Tis the notorioust mixture of a villaine,
That euer yet was bred vnder the dunghill
Of seruitude. Hee has more whores at command,
Then you haue horses. He has stables for them,
His priuate vawting houses.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Discharge him the house.
Take his accounts and office, and dispose them.

sp.speaker: Snarle.
sp.p: Euer your Lordships true and faythfull seruant.

sp.speaker: Milles.
sp.p: When was my Father, and the Captaine heere?

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: They are plotting abroad, I hope to see you shortly
Honestly marryed, and then turne vertuous.

sp.speaker: Milles.
sp.l: Tis the course of the world now, Margery.
But yet I feare, I haue got such a tricke,
When I was young, that I shall neuer leaue it.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: What helpe then? the poore Gentleman must suffer,
Good Trimalchio: tis his fate.

sp.speaker: Milles.
sp.l: I am thinking,
What I shall do with him, when I am marryed.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: What do other women do with their husbands?
Bring him vp in obedience, make him besides
An implement to saue your reputation.
Let him not presse into your company
Without permission, you must pretend,
You are asham'd of him. Let him not eate,
Nor lye with you, vnlesse he pay the hire
Of a new gowne, or petticote: liue with him,
As if you were his neighbour, onely neere him,
In that you hate his friends: and when you please.
To shew the power you carry ouer him,
Send him before on foot, and you come after
With your coach and foure horses.

sp.speaker: Milles.
sp.l: Tis fitting so
Host now what peece of motion haue wee heere
Would you speake with any body?

sp.speaker: Miscel.
sp.l: My businesse,
Is to the Lady Millescent.

sp.speaker: Miscel.
sp.l: To you then I derect my apologie.
It seemes your eye with approbation,
Has glanc'd vpon my person. I protest
I neuer was so dull in the construction
Of any Ladyes fauour in my life:
I am asham'd of my error.

sp.speaker: Milles.
sp.l: In what, sir?
I can not call to mind that ere I saw you.

sp.speaker: Miscel.
sp.l: You haue beene still too modest to conceale it.
That was not my fault: you did ill to striue
To hide the flames of loue, they must haue vent:
Tis not the walls of flesh can hold them in.

sp.speaker: Milles.
sp.l: What riddles haue we heere? that I should loue you?
I would not haue you thinke so wel of your selfe.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: Perhaps hee has some petition to deliuer,
Or would desire your letter to some Lord.

sp.speaker: Misce.
sp.l: I know not how, sure I was stupifyed,
I haue ere now ghest at a Ladyes mind,
Only by the warbling of her Lutestring,
Kissing her hand, or wagging of her feather,
And suffer you to pine for my imbraces,
And not conceiue it?

sp.speaker: Milles.
sp.l: Pray bee pacified.
This fellow will perswade me, I am in loue.

sp.speaker: Miscel.
sp.l: Lady, you haue tooke notice of my worth
Let it not repent you. Bee not stubborne
Towards your happinesse. You haue endur'd
Too much already for my sake, you shall see,
Pitty can melt my heart. I take no delight,
To haue a Lady languish for my lioe.
I am not made of flint as you suspect mee.

sp.speaker: Milles.
sp.l: I would thou wert conuerted to a pillar,
For a memoriall of this impudence.

sp.speaker: Miscel.
sp.l: You shall know what tis to tempt me heereafter,
When I shall let you perish for your folly.
I came to remunerate the curtesie,
I receiu'd from your Ladiship.

sp.speaker: Miscel.
sp.p: I must acknowledge my selfe bound to you

sp.speaker: Miscel.
sp.l: Your Letter to the Iustice, Lady,
It freed me from the pounces of those varlets,
When I was vnder the gripe of the Law.
I know, the onely motiue was your loue.

sp.speaker: Milles.
sp.l: I cry you mercy, were you one of them
That drew Trimalchio to those idle courses?
I am ashamed of the benefit, leaue mee
That I may not see the cause of my sorrow:
But 'tis no matter, we shall leaue you first.

sp.speaker: Miscel.
sp.l: They shall find, I am no man to be slighted,
And that shee has misplac'd her affection.
When I haue wrackt the wrongs on my corriuall,
Trimalchio, looke to thy selfe, were hee remou'd,
There might be hopes, my valour shall make known
There is a difference. Ile straight to the tauerne:
And when I once am hot with good Canary,
I pronounce him dead that affronts my fury.

sp.speaker: Ardelio.
sp.l: Turn'd out of seruice the next turne will be
Vnder the Gallows, and haue a Ballad made of me,
The corruption of a casheer'd Seruing-man,
Is the generation of a thiefe. I scare,
My fate poynts me not out to so good fortune.
My bulke will not serue me to take a purse.
The best thing I am fit for, is a tapster,
Or else get a wench of mine owne, and sell
Bottell Ale and Tobacco, that's my refuge
They tearmd me parasite, 'tis a mystery
Is like a familiar, that leaues a man
When he is neere his execution.
I haue no power to flatter my selfe now,
I might haue gone a wooing to some widdow,
And had his countenance, but now the tenants
Looke like their Bacon, rustily, vpon me.
What, Ieffery! thou art the comfort of my woes:
Welcome, good Ieffry.

sp.speaker: Ieff.
sp.l: Very wel, sir.
Lockt in a Cypresse chest, for feare of Moths.

sp.speaker: Aed.
sp.p: And all the other furniture good Ieffry.

sp.speaker: Ieff.
sp.p: They are kept safe, and well ary'd for your Worship.

sp.speaker: Ardel.
sp.l: Thanks, good Ieffry. I were in a sweet case,
If I had not conuayd somethings away,
To maintaine mee hereafter.

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.l: I may go set vp bils now for my liuing,
Cry Vineger vp and downe the streets; or fish
At blacke Fryers stayres; or sit against
A wall, with a library of ballads before mee.

sp.speaker: Ieff.
sp.p: You are not out of seruice.

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.l: Turnd a grazing,
In the wide Common of the world, Ieffry.

sp.speaker: Ieff.
sp.l: Then are my hopes at best, I haue no reason
To care for him any longer; a word with you.
What furniture do you meane?

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.l: Those that I sent,
The beds, and hangings.

sp.speaker: Ardel.
sp.p: I hope you will not vse mee so.

sp.speaker: Ieff.
sp.l: Your owne words.
I must make the best benefit of my place:
You know, tis not an age to bee honest in.
Tis the only high-way vnto pouerty.
I know not how, I do not fancy you
Of late.

sp.speaker: Arde.
sp.l: I chose thee for thy knauish looke.
And now thou hast requited mee: of all
My euils, thou art the worst.

sp.speaker: Ieff.
sp.l: No fayth, sir.
You haue a worse commodity at my house.
But you may saue the charges of a writ.
Ile send her you without reprieue or bayle.
I doe you that fauour.

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.p: No, you may keepe her still.

sp.speaker: Ieff.
sp.l: My thinkes you are much deiected with your fall,
I finde an alteration in your face.
You looke like an Almanacke of last yeeres date.
Or like your liuery cloake, of two yeeres wearing.
Worse then the smoaky wall of a bawdy house.

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.p: Villaine, dost thou insult on me?

sp.speaker: Ieff
sp.l: No fayth sir,
Alasse, tis not within the reach of man,
To countermine your plots.

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.l: Well, slaue, because
Ile rid my hands of thee, Ile giue thee a share.

sp.speaker: Ieff.
sp.l: You must haue none, without lawfull proceeding.
And that I know, you dare not.

sp.speaker: Snarle.
sp.l: But I dare.
Haue you beene partners all this while in mischiefe,
And now fall out, who shall bee the most knaue?

sp.speaker: Snarle.
sp.l: I meane to search your house
For ammunition, no otherwise,
Which I suspect you send vnto the Leager.

sp.speaker: Ieff.
sp.l: Sir I haue nothing there, but one crackt piece
Belongs to this Gentleman, can doe no seruice.
She is spoyld in the bore.

sp.speaker: Snarle.
sp.l: Wee'l haue her new cast.
Come, bring them away.

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.l: Nay good sir, you know,
That I was lately quit before a Iustice.
And if I fall in a relapse.

sp.speaker: Snarle.
sp.l: Al's one
To me, but you must satisfie the Law.

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.p: Well then, I know the worst of it.

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.p: Master Trimalchio, 'tis an age since I saw you.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: I was nere out of towne.

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.l: Not out of towne?
We sought you about all the Ordinaries,
Tauernes and Bawdyhouses, we could imagine
You euer haunted.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: You might haue found vs then.

sp.speaker: Antol.
sp.p: Nay more, we inquir'd at the Play-houses.

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.p: 'Twas once in my minde, to haue had you cryed.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: Well, shall I tell you, Captaine?

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: This Gentleman and I
Haue past through purgatory, since I saw you.
If I should tell you all the passages
At the Leager.

sp.speaker: Antol.
sp.l: Thither we came to meete you,
And you were gone.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: 'Tis such a story
Would fill a Chronicle.

sp.speaker: Capr.
sp.l: We met with a party of the enemies,
Tooke all we had from vs, and then it cost vs
Forty shillings in fees at the Iustices.

sp.speaker: Capr.
sp.l: The old boy and I
Grew to be kin at last.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: He made me sure
To my mistris, before we parted.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: Honest Ardelio,
And Misellanio, wee were all together
In rebellion, and quit by a Letter,
That came from my mistresse.

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.l: Ist possible?
And Miscellanio turne traytor?

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.l: Would haue your mistresse from you, thinkes the Letter
Was sent for his sake.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: That I am sure hee does not.

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.p: Threatens, and sweares that he wil fight for her.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: If hee bee weary of his life, hee may.
Why what can hee pretend to her?

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.l: I know not,
What has past betweene them, but I am sure,
He has beene practising at the Fencing schoole,
To get a trick to kill you.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: Hee kill mee!
I'll kill him first. I fight by Geometry.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: Yes sir, heere I hold
My Rapier, marke mee, in a diameter
To my body; thats the center, conceiue mee.

sp.speaker: Antol.
sp.p: Your body is the center, very good.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: And my hilt, part of the circumference.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: Which hilt is bigger then my body.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: Yes at such a distance.
And hee shall neuer hit mee, whilst hee liues.

sp.speaker: Antol.
sp.p: Where did you learne this? At the leager?

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: No.
No by this light: it is my owne inuention.
I learnt it in my trauels.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: Very strange:
You are a scholler.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.l: No: I would not bee
suspected of such a crime for a Million.
But tis no sinne to know Geometry;
And by that, I can tel wee shal nere fight.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: I'l shew you in Geometry,
Two paralels can neuer meet: now wee two
Being paralels, for so wee are, that is
Equal in wit and valour, can neuer meet.
And if wee neuer meet, wee shal nere fight.

sp.speaker: Antol.
sp.p: To proue your axiome false, see where hee comes.

sp.speaker: Miscel.
sp.l: Hang thee blustring sonne
Of Aeolus, defy me! I'll tye vp thy breath
In bags, and sell it for a penny an ounce.

sp.speaker: Capri.
sp.l: Sure, this is the second part of the Leager.
Twere best for me, to hide mee in my cabin.

sp.speaker: Miscel.
sp.p: Vnlesse you'l haue her tane away by force.

sp.speaker: Antol.
sp.p: I see, this cannot be ended without bloud.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: I am afrayd he comes with the blacke art.

sp.speaker: Antol.
sp.p: How you afrayd? do not say so for shame.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: Hee has layne with an old witch at Sweden.
And is growne sticke free.

sp.speaker: Antol.
sp.p: Fy that you shall say so.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: I'll be resolu'd of that before I fight.

sp.speaker: Antol.
sp.p: Why, do you thinke that witches haue such power?

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: I marry do I, I haue knowne one of them,
Do more then that, when her husband has followed
Strange women, shee has turnd him into a Bezer,
And made him bite out his owne stones.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: I'll tell you another as strange as that, of one
When a Vintner has sent her but ill wine,
Shee has conuerted him into a Frog.
And then coniur'd him into one of his butts,
Where hee has liued twelue moneths vpon the lees,
And when his old ghests chance to come to see him,
Hee has croackt to them, out at the bunghole.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: There was a Lawyer
That spoke against one of them at the barre.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: Turnd him into a Ram,
And still that Ram retaynes his profession,
Has many Clients, and pleads causes as well
As some Lawyers in Westminster.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: Do you thinke,
That hee has had recourse to any such?

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: I know not, but tis good to bee mistrustfull.
Hee may haue aduantage in the encounter.

sp.speaker: Miscel.
sp.p: There she comes, winne her, and weare her.

sp.speaker: Milles.
sp.l: Hold your hands.
I'll haue no bloud a prologue to my wedding.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: Nay then haue at you. Hold mee not, I saye
I am as fierce as hee.

sp.speaker: Milles.
sp.l: Bee pacified.
I thought you had beene both bound to the peace.

sp.speaker: Antol.
sp.l: Lady, it seemes, that these two Gentlemen
Do stand in competition for your loue.

sp.speaker: Milles.
sp.l: Mr. Trimalchio, I confesse, has beene
A former suitor, but with his ill carriage,
He has thus long preuented his good fortune.

sp.speaker: Antol.
sp.p: Then let mee make a motion.

sp.speaker: Antol.
sp.p: Will they both stand to it?

sp.speaker: Autol.
sp.p: Then let the Lady dispose of her selfe.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: Shee is mine already. I am sure to her,
Before a Iustice.

sp.speaker: Miscel.
sp.l: I will haue no woman,
Against her will.

sp.speaker: Milles.
sp.l: No sir, nor you shall not,
Since you are so peremptory, on your words then
That hee shall sing a Palinodium,
And recant his ill courses, I assume
My Loue Trimalehio.

sp.speaker: Capri.
sp.p: Do wee take, or are we taken?

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.l: Who's that, Capritio? where haue you beene?
Come your wayes forth, and lay hands on the spoyle.
Goe lead away that Lady by the hand.
Now you may take occasion by the foretop,
Aduance your owne predominant the better,
And march away,

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: Come, let vs to the Church.

sp.speaker: Miscel.
sp.p: And what must I do now? bee laught at?

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.l: Would you
Hazard your selfe, for one that cares not for you?
You may be glad you scap't. Recall your selfe.
Were not you formerly engagd?

sp.speaker: Miscel.
sp.l: Fayth we haue toy'd
In iest sometime.

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.l: Let it bee now in earnest.
Make her amends. I know shee loues you.

sp.speaker: Miscel.
sp.l: Well.
I will haue her, and stand vp for my portion,
With the rest of my tribe.

div.head: Scena vltima.

sp.speaker: Snarle
sp.l: Stay heere a little, they are gone to Church,
And will returne in couples. First, Trimalchio,
That Gyant in conceit, thinkes he is matcht
To some great heire, but shall imbrace a cloud
In stead of Iuno. Then her waiting woman,
Her Iris, reflects vpon Capritio,
And for my piece of fragmentary Courtship,
My Miscellany Gentleman, 'tis his lot
To bee cast vpon Quartilla with Agurtes
In his old Iusticeship. All these march together,
Like the seuen deadly sinnes, and behind them,
Comes Autolicus, the clarke of the company.

div.stage: Trimalchio, Millescent. Miscellanio, Quartilla, Capritio, Margery, Antolicus like a Clarke,

sp.speaker: Antol.
sp.p: Looke you sir, here they come.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: Make roome, me thinkes
You should not stop the course of Iustice so.
My Lord Philantus, you are welcome from
The Warres, and I from the Church. I wonder
Who makes the better returne, you haue got
Honour, and so haue I. But wher's your wealth?
I can imbrace fiue thousand pounds, a yeere.
That's nothing with you, I haue no more wit,
Then to be pi'd by pimpes, and marry whoores,
Yet I meane shortly to ranke with your honour.
Here is my warrant, I haue promisd her,
To make her a Countesse, but thats nothing with you,
Nay, more then this I can goe on, and leaue
Some aduancement: behind me. Ecce signum,

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Tis well, I am glad of your happinesse,
And much ioy to my brother Capritio,
And his faire spouse.

sp.speaker: Capri.
sp.l: She is according to
My hearts desire, sir.

sp.speaker: Snarle.
sp.l: Well, a word with you,
Master Trimalchio, and the rest.

sp.speaker: Snarle.
sp.l: You were as good know it at first, as at last.
You are not the first, that haue beene deceiued.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: In what? my wife? I married her for a mayd.
And whether she be one, or no, I care not.

sp.speaker: Snarle.
sp.l: Nay, should I heare a man that should abuse her
In that, I would defend her with my sword.
But she and you must call this man your father.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: I so she must, hee gaue her at the Church.

sp.speaker: Snarl
sp.l: Nay, her owne naturall father, flesh and bone,
I hope shee'l not deny it.

sp.speaker: Milles.
sp.l: No indeede, sir.
I wou'd not liue to be so vngracious.

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.l: I must acknowledge thee my child, or I
Should doe thy mother wrong.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: I doe not thinke so,
You'l not make me beleeue that I tooke her
For a Lords daughter, and a great heire. Where are
Agurtes and the Captaine to iustifie it?
Is hee your father?

sp.speaker: Milles.
sp.l: He has euer bred mee:
And I haue alwayes cal'd him so. I hope
It is no shame: my parentage is honest.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: Well, if hee bee, tis no disparagement,
To marry a Iustices daughter.

sp.speaker: Snarle.
sp.l: Come, you haue
Beene carryed hood winkt through this businesse.
Nor is the day yet cleere before you. Marke mee;
I'll open but one leafe in all the booke,
And you shall see the whole discouery.
Come sir, vnease.

div.stage: Agurtes and Antolicus pull off there disguises.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: Who haue we heere? Agurtes
And the Captaine? Was't you that playd the Iustice?
And you his clarke?

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: Then you are a knot of knaues for your labour.
Now I perceiue that I am playnly guld.

sp.speaker: Capr.
sp.p: I am glad ther's no man cheated but himselfe.

sp.speaker: Snarle.
sp.l: Your arrow is one of the same quiuer too.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: Ile none of her by this light.

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.l: Why, you may chuse.
And yet I doe not well see, how you can chuse.
She is your wife, and you haue married her,
And must allow her meanes to maintayne her.
You may declare your selfe vnto the world.
And bee laught at: but keepe your owne counsell,
And who needs know of it?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Beleeue me sir,
The Gentlewoman is not to be despisde,
Her wit and vertues are dowry sufficient.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: Nay, if you say so, then must I needs loue her:
But by this hand, I thought you would haue jeer'd me.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Hold on your course, march on as you came in,
And rest content, since fate has thought it fit,
To make your fortunes equall with your wit.
